Despite some missteps common to the adventure game genre, and a third act that loses itself in the details and machinations of its fantasy world, The Night of the Rabbit is a journey adventure game fans won’t regret or soon forget.

A solid adventure game that genre veterans will undoubtedly eat up. Novices, however, may be put off by the game’s issues. If they are patient enough, however, they will find an enjoyable and enchanted world to explore.
The puzzles themselves threaten to end the bunnymoon, however, occasionally provoking ire with nonsensical logic. [Aug 2013, p.74]
The Night of the Rabbit is a great adventure, but it has its issues. It's a very imaginative experience.
Quotation forthcoming.

The Night of the Rabbit is great for the newcomers to adventure games – this fairytale will open up a whole new genre for them. Veteran players can safely skip it, and the only thing they’ll miss is a couple of mice peddlers – two of the best supporting characters ever made by Deadalic.

The design could be tighter, the story a bit better paced, but it's still a fine couple of evenings' worth of puzzling, atmosphere, mystery, and magic, with animals cute and fluffy enough to see you through its more turgid bits. [Oct 2013, p.69]
The Night of the Rabbit wins easy points for its beautiful imagery, clever puzzles and dialogue, but the experience is held back by substandard animations and a lack of mechanical polish.
It breaks my heart to even talk about The Night of the Rabbit in a negative manner because, while it has its issues, it’s still an imaginative experience.

While we shouldn’t ignore its problems with the flow of the story and illogical puzzles, this shouldn’t stop anyone who is a follower of the genre from jumping into this world of magic and talking animals to enjoy one kid’s dream of a delightful summer adventure.

The Night of the Rabbit is a good Graphical Adventure game: graphically inspired and with an important soundtrack... but it's far from the milestones of the genre due to the slow narration, the lengthy dialogues, and some inevitable bugs. It even lacks in terms of localization for many countries.

The Night of the Rabbit looks like a kid oriented game, but the puzzles point it towards the hardcore audience. One may clear them with a little research, but it's clear Daedalic didn't really master its difficulty curve. But in terms of production values and story, it's really good.
The Night of the Rabbit is a beautiful adventure with only a few pacing and puzzle quirks to trip you up along the way.

The Night of the Rabbit is yet another great adventure game from the minds of Daedalic Entertainment. The dialogues are a bit childish but the puzzles and visuals are really good. Overall it's a very solid game.
The Night of the Rabbit will make players wish that magic was real. The game’s charming world builds Jerry’s final adventure in his summer as something memorable and magical.

The Night of the Rabbit is an adventure that creates a wonderful magic world around it’s held Jeremia Haselnuss and brings nice characters to virtual life. But as wonderful as Daedalic Entertainment built the fantasy world with lots of details around the little boy Jeremias who wants to become a magician, they present the dialogues in a boring way and they sometimes even confuse story itself. The game also lacks hints for the puzzles which often only allow the one solution that even is the most digressive. The player doesn’t get sufficient feedback while trying to solve the puzzles, whatever there are from hints or out of dialogues with other characters. Because of this the game sometimes gets really frustrating and forces you into trial and error. Players expecting a game with the usual quality of Daedalic adventures such as the Deponia-series will be disappointed.
If you can look beyond the narrative shortcomings you’ll get a solid adventure set in a captivating fairy tale world.

After Deponia’s rather positive reception, however, I expected more from Daedalic. The dialogue being rather childish is to be expected from a 12 year old protagonist and I’d consider this game aimed at the younger generation. That being said, the difficulty of juggling multiple quest lines simultaneously is not for the easily distracted, or the easily frustrated.

A bunch of interesting characters, polished visuals and a decent soundtrack are not enough for me to remember The Night of the Rabbit. Writers missed a couple of opportunities to astonish the player and therefore wasted the potential of a promising story. [CD-Action 08/2013, p.72]
The Night of the Rabbit is not without its missteps, but when at its best the game is hard to resist.

While its atmosphere and overall world manage to conjure wonderful memories from our long lost childhood, the bad flow of the story, the ridiculous characters and the severely underwhelming puzzles make this game a lacking addition to the great roster of Daedelic.

Despite its classic metaphoric coming of age storyline, despite its lovingly drawn backgrounds that seem to have sprung to life from the pages of children’s stories and despite the innocuous language and childish humour, the incongruous nature of the frustrating puzzles will thwart children unfamiliar with the ancient lore of point and click adventures.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: A straight port but in HD of the classic and epic 3DS cult action adventure game. An interesting buy option for newcomers.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: It feels limited some times, something we can understand taking into account that it comes from a 3DS version. However, if you’re a fan of the subseries created by MercurySteam and if you haven’t played before, it’s a game you should play.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Castlevania: Mirror of Fate HD is a competent porting of the second entry in the reboot orchestrated by Mercury Steam.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror Of Fate is a solid but not outstanding action game. Despite the lacking of finishing touches, the game presents a lot of good quality action moments and it's perfect for awaiting Lords of Shadow 2.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: It fills up the gap between both Lords of Shadow games quite nicely and the HD-transition is well-done. Nevertheless, the game's a bit easy, the gameplay lacks depth and the story could have been a lot more engaging. It will keep Castlevania fans busy until Lords of Shadow 2 is released, which is the only reason we could come up with to recommend this.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: It’s not Symphony of the Night, but if you’re a long-time fan, you must whip it. [Christmas 2013, p82]

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Although the game can look a little rough around the edges, it's still a thoroughly worthy addition to the blood-soaked legacy of Castlevania. [Jan 2014, p.94]

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Though Mirror of Fate's HD upgrade looks great and its entertaining combat is a good move forward for the franchise, it doesn't reach the heights of its predecessor.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate is a fun and engaging game, but it doesn't live up to the Castlevania name and it's very disappointing from a technical standpoint.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Upgrading the visuals to high definition is not enough to conceal its origins as a portable game, nor to hide the problems the original game had.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Castlevania: Lords of Shadow – Mirror of Fate HD is a fun ride and will take you some time to play through. It also looks good, especially for being a port of a Nintendo 3DS handheld title and will provide fans with more of the Belmont history than you could find on Ancestry.com.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate on the 3DS may not have been the side-scrolling, vampire-hunting adventure that we all hoped it would be, but with its heightened presentation and revamped mechanics, Mirror of Fate HD is a big step in the right direction.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate HD offers a special and cheap opportunity to discover what happened in Dracula's Castle years ago. This is the same game released on Nintendo 3DS in terms of contents with some visual improvements. Don't expect a full HD-redesigned experience.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Solid conversion of the 3DS vampire hunt. Unfortunately you won’t get any new content nor improvements in any form.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: If you have already been down this road, there is really nothing here to warrant a second play, however if you haven’t played the second entry in the Lords of Shadow narrative, this is the one to get.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Still, this is a smartly executed return to the kind of gameplay that made Castlevania great, and we'd love to see it grow into something more. [Jan 2014, p.85]

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: This is the best version of the game, without a doubt, but it’s the best version of a game that is still, at it’s core, good without ever crossing the threshold into great.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Castlevania: Lords of Shadow – Mirror of Fate HD presented MercurySteam with a chance to correct many of the original release’s problems and glaring issues. What we ended up getting was an airlifted port with the only new addition being online leaderboards. Sure, the gameplay is tighter on a controller, but that doesn’t make this lazy port any better than the original release.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Anyone who expects Lords of Shadow 2 and would like to know more about the mythology developed by Mercury Steam has to go through this title. If the 3DS version has not already landed in your hands, you can rely on this HD port.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Overall, this is a game that will likely divide Castlevania fans. It’s still that a dark and forbidding fairy tale told that worked so well on the 3DS. It doesn’t quite fit as well here but it does manage to create some of the same atmospheric, dark and brutal adventure and if more people get a chance to experience it then that can only be a good thing. Its home is clearly on the 3DS though.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: A good graphic lifting that hides a lazy porting of the original 3DS game.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: The experience here is exactly the same as the one from the 3DS edition -which is good- and the story is essential for those who wish to follow the lore from the Lords of Shadow franchise.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: There's a touch of imprecision that can make platforming a little on the sluggish side. [Christmas 2013, p.105]

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: It’s not the best Castlevania game ever, but for a digitally distributed minor title it’s really decent. And the visuals are surprisingly good for a game initially created for the 3DS. [01/2014, p.62]

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: The game is worth a prod though because the feeling can’t be matched. It’s a classic game, with most of the best elements, tossed into a nifty hitch of a game ported over from the DS.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate got away with its shortcomings on a handheld, but on the big screen it becomes painfully obvious how much it falls short. With exactly the same problems and no additions worth mentioning, Mirror of Fate HD resembles a toothless vampire: harmless and worthy of the name Dracula.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: A vastly better game than Lords Of Shadow 2, that smooths the rough edges from the 3DS original and proves that Castlevania need not revert back to a niche retro franchise.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Like the series itself, there's satisfaction to be had in sticking to the well-worm path. [June 2014, p.91]

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: It's a compromise between action and exploration, between the series' history and contemporary trends, between traditional presentation and modern technology. It's the best Castlevania game we've played in years and it might be the best action game we've ever played on a handheld console.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Its mixture older-style exploration with LoS' combat results in not only a truly great Castlevania game, but also a great action title and one of the best offerings on Nintendo's console.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mercury Steam creates a videogame that supposes another interesting reboot in the Castlevania franchise, this time from the 2D perspective. A title with Metroidvania elements, a strong combat system and 10 hours of gameplay. Mirror of Fate is one of the best games designed for Nintendo 3DS.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate manages to make the once well-worn Metroidvania formula new again by using this reboot-based version of the franchise, and is a must-play for any fans of the series.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Despite being neither revolutionary nor completely true to the original Castlevania concept, Mirror of Fate is enormously entertaining in its own right. It is a delightful mixture of action, platforming and exploration featuring a satisfying combat system that works extremely well in 2D.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Boss fights are fun and varied, and the excellent checkpointing system kept the big encounters from becoming frustrating. Castlevania fans and 3DS owners alike will find a lot to enjoy here.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: An impressive follow-up to 2010's Lords of Shadow that you shouldn't miss.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate takes its cues from MercurySteam’s 2010 console title, Lords of Shadow, and mixes in some light Metroid exploration elements. Once you’ve got your head around that, you’re in for an adventure that successfully fuses Castlevania’s new flavor with the franchise’s 2D roots.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: One of the best platforming and action games on 3DS. It's a must-have on the handheld, and works perfectly no matter if you've played Castlevania: Lords of Shadow or not.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate is a confident interpretation of well-trod mechanics and themes, and the Castlevania name is stronger for it.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: I personally enjoy the 2D Castlevania titles, so I was skeptical to play Mirror of Fate. Of course, I was also skeptical of another developer taking over one of the most beloved franchises in gaming history, and that turned out pretty great. Now we see MercurySteam taking the same approach to the franchise in the handheld space, and again with decent results.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: After changing the longstanding mechanics of Castlevania with Lords of Shadow, MercurySteam managed to merge action and exploration in Mirror of Fate. The game is far from the Metroidvania style but in exchange offers many hours of intense combat, and a story that studies in the Belmont family mythology. If only the platforming and puzzle solving were better, this could be the perfect successor to Symphony of the Night; but unfortunately it is not but it's a great 3DS game and a thrilling interlude while we wait for Lords of Shadows 2.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Atmosphere so thick you can crack it with a whip. [May 2013, p.78]

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: For those who really missed the Metroidvania concept of Koji Igarashi in Lords of Shadow, MercurySteam has created in Mirror of Fate an petit homage with the style and gameplay of the reboot's series, adding those elements of pure exploration, platforms and astonishing 3D's visual stereoscopic levels that truly take us into the castle, dungeons and caves of the new & tragic Dracula, always cursed by the revenge of the Belmont Clan.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: With Mirror of Fate the iconic franchise finally returns to the 2D world - with success. This way back to its roots is definitely enjoyable, but still something's missing to reach the grandeur of the series’ famous installments. Nevertheless, both gameplay and visuals are great. There are some minor balancing problems, but all in all Mirror of Fate is a must-have for fans of the genre.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: The best portable Castlevania for years and a more than equal follow-up to Lords Of Shadow – not to mention one of the best-looking games so far on the 3DS.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Although the 2D perspective and Metroidvania-style features call to mind past classics, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow - Mirror of Fate shouldn’t be directly compared to previous games in Konami’s long-running vampire-hunting series, because it tries to do things a little differently.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: A huge thrill-a-minute adventure, with satisfying combat, and big boss fights. Just don't expect the old Metroidvania formula.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mercury Steam continues to demonstrate its talent in this new contribution to its Lords of Shadow reboot of the Castlevania series. Beautifully transposed to 2,5D gameplay, this 3DS title brings back together demanding platforming and deep combat mechanics, in an accessible mix that only lacks a little more puzzles and, for old-timers, challenge.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: As Lords of Shadow, Mirror of Fate stands out not only for its massive amount of content, but also for some well polished gameplay mechanics, like it's great combat system.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate is as enjoyable reboot, if you will, to an age-old franchise. The game has all the right elements to make it fun and enjoyable. Sure, it has a few issues but fans of the series, and genre as a whole, will most likely love it even if it does bristle with the liberties in the storyline. That being said, the casual fan may have trouble with the sometimes-tough control and dark undertones of the subject material.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Like Bram Stoker’s famous book Dracula, the source material on which the series is based, Castlevania continues to evolve and reinvent itself for new audiences.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate is an excellent entry into this new Castlevania canon. It treats its plot with as much reverence as a home console title, while capturing more of the feel of classic Castlevania than Lords of Shadow. It's an excellent companion piece to Gabriel's first adventure, and a thoughtful, well-designed handheld title in particular.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: If you liked Castlevania: Lords of Shadows, you'll like Mirror of Fate. Mercury Steam succeed in combining the basis of Konami's reboot and some old stuffs from the early episodes. The result is ten hours of an intense and gripping adventure that will lead you to the end of Dracula's reign. The choice between four characters is very welcome, exactly like the renewal in the gameplay. A successful bet.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate is almost a unique offer and that is what is essential when you immerse yourself in this crossed destiny of four characters.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Overall, this is a game that will likely divide Castlevania fans. Taken on its own merit we can only recommend this to 3DS owners. It’s a dark and forbidding fairy tale told with skill and it conjures an atmospheric adventure which leads into the darker, more brutal side of the Castlevania universe.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: The dynamic battles are well executed, the 3D-effects strike you with immense feeling of depth. But Mercury Steam can’t get a grip on the spirit of past mobile Castlevanias. This plays more like a two-dimensional God of War than a modern variation of the cult vampire saga.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: The new direction Castlevania has taken can be liked or not, and we personally fall into the latter category, but Mirror of Fate is nonetheless a very good, albeit not perfect, action game for 3DS. If only it was devoid of that tedious quick time events.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: If fans come in expecting something more like Castlevania IV than Symphony of the Night, they're in for a good experience. More than anything though, Mirror of Fate has me excited for Lords of Shadow 2.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate doesn’t do much terribly wrong, but doesn’t do much greatly either. All parts are subjected to a story that doesn’t live up to standards. It’s party Lords of Shadow with a deep, perfectly integrated combat system that hardly gets put to the test. It’s partly Metroidvania, but exploration doesn’t have a great impact due to lackluster upgrades. When holding Mirror of Fate up to a mirror, it mostly misses a clear execution of a number of good ideas.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: The game looks great and the gameplay is fantastic, but it never becomes too hard. The storyline that was so great in the original is not that clear in this game.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: While Mirror of Fate might willingly fumble the classic structure somewhat, it's still got a touch of that familiar vampire-hunting charm to it - a charm that comes to the rescue whenever the developer's invention or polish fall short.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Three times the protagonists gives you three times the number of toys and an engaging, if thoroughly convoluted, story, but it’s not without cost. What Simon, Trevor and Alucard give to the mechanics and narrative they take from its flow: you still feel gated, even when you’ve got all the gear.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Much like its title, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow — Mirror of Fate plays with multiple concepts attempting to garner widespread appeal, but would be better suited focusing on just one.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Purists will be pleased, then, with Mirror of Fate for the Nintendo 3DS. Although excessively subtitled, it’s a return to the series’ two-dimensional side-scrolling roots, which is both a good and a bad thing. While the exploration and clever puzzle-solving is front and centre again, so too is an unfortunate side effect – a healthy dose of backtracking.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: With Castlevania: Lords of Shadow – Mirror of Fate MercurySteams follows its own way of thinking about the epic Konami franchise. The developers did a good job in capturing Castlevania’s soul, but the game’s soundtrack and level design aren’t good enough to stand a chance against the other portable episodes of the series. It’s still a good and entertaining game, anyway.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate is a fun and occasionally challenging action game with successful elements and an unfortunate, but small, selection of poor design choices.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: These complaints ultimately make Castlevania: Lords of Shadow- Mirror of Fate disposable and just short of being considered a classic, but so long as you except the game for what it is, you'll most likely have a zombie-whipping good time.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate is not your typical handheld Castlevania adventure: with a more predictable map exploration and a weapon and magic variety reduced to its lowest terms, it sets itself as a portable version of the Lords of Shadow saga. Mercury Steam has put some distance between what Konami and Igarashi achieved in the past ten+ years: this is a somewhat good action/fighting game, but a less-then-stellar Castlevania experience, plagued by a questionable frame rate.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate is basically a 2D God of War, so if you dig platformers with decent combat mechanics, you’ll most likely enjoy it.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Mirror of Fate is a good game. Take Lords of Shadow, cut the playing time in half, limit the third dimension to an optical illusion and what remains is an action adventure game that plays like a dream. The only real concession that was made is a story that hardly adds anything, which makes this feel more like a spin-off. That's a shame, because it was supposed to be the link between Lords of Shadow and LoS 2.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Castlevania Lords of Shadow: Mirror of Fate is an average action game, far from the feeling of its predecessor.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: The Nintendo 3DS seems to be struggling of fully perform all of the great ideas of the latest Castlevania adventure. Still, this is highly recommended for all fans of the series.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: The game holds me down with its vampire-like claws from the start and all the way until the end when the credits roll. But it never manages to sink its teeth into me and fully win me over to the other side. Afterwards, I break free without any trouble and wander out into the sunlight, while leaving the game in the darkness as I get ready for my next adventure with something else.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: There's nothing inherently wrong with linearity here; Mirror of Fate is just lacking an easily discernible big picture, and often conflates errand-running for intricacy. It's also unevenly paced, with all the solid puzzles sedimenting in the game's middle.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: In trying to distance itself a little bit from the formula that 2D Metroidvanias have now stuck to for the past 15 years, Mirror of Fate succeeded in most areas but falls a little bit too short in others.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Τranslating Lords of Shadow into a side-scrolling experience with Mirror of Fate was a successful experiment, though its shortcomings in some areas prevent it from achieving perfection. Even so, it's definitely worth playing.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Although Mirror of Fate doesn't live up to its full potential, it often comes close. I can see the beginnings of a fantastic new-school Castlevania experience trying hard to emerge here, and with just a little more polish and precision, MercurySteam would have turned out a solid winner. It's not yet fully evolved, but the work done here is still a valid step towards the future state of this ever-changing series.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: All things considered, Mirror of Fate is still a decent game, one that is merely injured by some elements of poor design. It’s a unique approach to rebooting a franchise, one that doesn’t seek to reestablish the rules, but instead utilize them as a guide, thus allowing this new version to travel its own direction.

game_title: castlevania: lords of shadow - mirror of fate
review_text: Castlevania: Mirror of Fate is stupid in a good way and robust enough to be an enjoyable challenge. While the boss battles go on a bit too long and the plot is bonkers, it’s a good use of a platforming style often forgotten.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: A wonderful game that rewards experimentation and co-operation.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: You could play straight through this game in a few hours, or dally with it for days. Therein lies its brilliance.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: A prodigiously enjoyable title. It has lots of action, violence, crazed humour and simple gameplay for pick up and play moments. It might be too easy and the multiplayer mode is not the best, but apart from those two minute annoyances there is nothing else you can fault it on.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It certainly isn't gaming's greatest challenge, but it's absolutely fun. If you've seen the original trilogy, don't resist! Join the LEGOside.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: This is, without a doubt, one of the best Star Wars games ever made, regardless of the age group.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Looks, feels, and plays like it's been designed by a group of people who love games, understand gamers and know how important it is to have fun. [Oct 2006, p.58]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Star Wars fans, LEGO fanatics or lovers of the first game will be in ecstasy. A must-buy. [Oct 2006, p.94]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Its kiddy facade hides some terrifically fun gameplay with a lot of meat on its bones.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: In a nutshell, LEGO Star Wars II is action, adventure, collecting, puzzles, races, mini-game, Co-op mode and your favorite Star Wars characters all having a great time.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Drop-in multiplayer, replay in spades, and optional objectives give players a reason to continue playing and get their money's worth out of this title. If you like fun, this is a great addition your gaming library, regardless of age or skill level.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: LSWII crams a whole lot of single and multiplayer fun into a game built- no pun intended- around Lego bricks and lightsabers.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Lego Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy is a winner, and deserves a second Alliance Medal of Honor. May the Force be with you -- always.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: A good example of a developer using an excellent license (in this case, two licenses) to its advantage.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Traveller's Tales has done it again: Lego Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy is an even quirkier blend of off-kilter humor, weird puzzles, and blaster-blazing, lightsaber-slashing action. [Oct. 2006, p.84]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: And, were it not said, someone would be drummed out of the union: The Force is strong with this one. [Oct. 2006, p.52]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: LEGO Star Wars II is a fun romp through the original trilogy of movies, and that crazy LEGO style really gives the whole thing a unique feel.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: The bottom line is that it's a heck of a lot of fun and has a great amount of replay value beyond a single play-through. Best family game this year? Probably so.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: A hilarious parody of Star Wars. The main problem is the camera in the co-op-game. The camera angle should be wider or it should pan more in the flying missions. [Sept 2006]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: If you know what size bra the Princess wears or the DNA make up of Darth Vadar, then this game is a must buy for you, and for everyone else I recommend at the very least renting this game and giving the co-op mode a shot, it is seriously that fun.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: And while the gameplay and puzzles are streamlined, the unlockable content massive, and the flying modes excellent, the best part about the game is its snarky humor and feel-good satire.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It’s a sequel to one of the most entertaining Star Wars games ever made, and it honors one of the best sci-fi trilogies of all time. Unfortunately, some of the design limitations might keep you from playing each level multiple times to find all the goodies and online achievements.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Very clever puzzles and fun action sequences will take you through the course of the Original Trilogy. The vehicular battles, especially with two people, are a real highlight.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Perhaps the only downside about Lego Star Wars II is that the melee combat remains weak throughout, some of the latter puzzles can be wilfully obscure, and that Traveller's Tales neglected to allow co-op to be played online. Apart from that, it's one of the most instantly enjoyable games around.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: With solidly rebuilt controls only a little marred by a still-fussy camera, LEGO Star Wars II is even better than last years prequel trilogy-based offering. And, as the first LEGO Star Wars was an amazingly entertaining homage to Lucas's genius, this sequel stands atop the original's shoulders as the pinnacle of LEGO Star Wars fun.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Like any good sequel, Lego Star Wars II improves on the original in almost every way. But most importantly, it's about the good episodes now. For that reason alone, Lego Star Wars II is one of the most enjoyable games of this fall.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Fans of Star Wars in general need to play this game and anyone looking for a break from all the shooters, racers, and RPGs flooding the market today owe it to themselves to check out this simple, yet highly addictive little action title.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Lego Star Wars graphics, sound, and gameplay all bring a classic trilogy to life with utter detail, and the added sense of humor and countless list of secrets and Achievements will keep you playing, even after the Empire's fallen at your feet.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: While this initial impression may cause some to write it off as “just for kids,” LEGO Star Wars II is as exciting an experience as any “adult” game out there and whole-heartedly recommended for fans of the film series.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: This entire game is held up by the comedy that it delivers, and as a result, I don't think I've laughed this hard in years. [Oct. 2006, p.95]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: If you have any fondness for Star Wars you'll find Lego Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy incredibly hard to resist. It's packed to the brim with fun and offers plenty of value despite what seems like a fairly short main story.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: But it would take a very hardcore Star Wars fan to actually plod on and replay the same levels again and again. As such, LSWII might be best rented.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: The melee is still a little simplistic and the camera can get in the way, but it really feels like you're in a Lego universe with some incredibly varied puzzles as well as some intense action.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: LEGO Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy goes out on a charm offensive and delivers on almost every level - you could argue that the gameplay is overly simplistic and repetitive, but with this much charisma and so much to explore and collect, it's hard not to be seduced.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It doesn't offer anything innovative, but it's good old-fashioned fun, which is something the Xbox 360 seems to be missing.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Lego Star Wars II takes a successful formula, enhances it ten fold and goes next generation.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Sure, it's no Halo; it's a simpler game free of such complexities, but it's a reminder of a time when bits of brightly-coloured plastic and an imagination were all you needed to have a good time.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Combining timeless events, great humour, simple yet effective gameplay, and just an astonishing amount of variety all in one little package, it’s hard not to find something about this game that makes you smile.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It's tough to recommend the Xbox 360 version over the much cheaper Xbox incarnation despite the enhanced graphics and performance, but Jedi Gamerscore-whores will no doubt pick it up for the fairly easy 1000 points it offers.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: A must-buy for both fans of plastic bricks and the “real” Star Wars movies. Combining a humorous take on the classic films with simple controls and tricky puzzles, this game is a standout in the seemingly never ending avalanche of repetitive Star Wars titles.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: The gameplay hasn't changed dramatically, but better source material makes Lego Star Wars II a better game than its predecessor.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: LEGO Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy will be a delight to play for any Star Wars fan, the story is short and can easily be completed in a weekend with out breaking a sweat, it will certainly be an enjoyable weekend though.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: You have to give credit to the brilliant blockhead who forced this awesome yet fundamentally bizarro idea on LucasArts. [Oct. 2006, p.111]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: A surprisingly challenging experience.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Everything is unabashedly cheerful... It's a shame that later levels begin to run out of steam, repeating tasks over and over as a contrivance for lengthening narrative. [Oct 2006, p.90]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: A game of several frustrating elements and simplistic gameplay that somehow manages to immerse and entertain. The condensed retelling of the trilogy is genuinely amusing (unless you've never seen a Star Wars movie before), whist the many, many secrets and unlockables provide a compelling hook to the largely simplistic romp.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: With a few exceptions, I felt all of the new features would have been better off left out, but the core gameplay is still there.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: My one complaint with this game is the flashing text. If you don’t have a 2nd player, the game continuously flashes ‘Insert Controller’, which can’t be turned off.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Some gameplay problems, but its charm and replayability helps to overcome them. [Issue #15]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Not concerned with complex game design or elaborate plot, The Original Trilogy sets out to do one thing only - please gaming SW fans the world over, and it achieves this admirably. [Issue 12, p.90]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: LSW2 is a quality title, but it suffers the same problem as the films it parodies.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: A wonderful game that rewards experimentation and co-operation.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: You could play straight through this game in a few hours, or dally with it for days. Therein lies its brilliance.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: The Co-Op mode alone makes this an essential purchase and now with the ability to take vehicles out for a spin and create new characters, Lego Star Wars II is every bit as great as we would have hoped.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It trumps the already brilliant original by being based on the classic trilogy of films and, in terms of gameplay, is the multiplayer co-op game of the decade so far.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It certainly isn't gaming's greatest challenge, but it's absolutely fun. If you've seen the original trilogy, don't resist! Join the LEGOside.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: While at its core, this is basically the same game as the first LEGO Star Wars, albeit based on a different trilogy, there is more here to do than the original. And more here is certainly better.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: I had such a good time blasting away at Stormtroopers and piloting speeder bikes through the forest of Endor that I almost forgot about my own fiery death. [Dec. 2006, p.124]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: This is the most pure fun I have had playing a game since... well, since the original LEGO Star Wars.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: In a nutshell, LEGO Star Wars II is action, adventure, collecting, puzzles, races, mini-game, Co-op mode and your favorite Star Wars characters all having a great time.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: There's some superb gaming here, no sci-fi indulgence, no grim Star Wars fanboyism, no recourse to statistics or tedious switch. This is an action-puzzle game for all brains great and small. [Oct 2006, p.94]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Gloriously fun and deeply silly, it's the happiest platform game of all. [Oct 2006, p.98]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: LEGO Star Wars II improves in every way on its predecessors, making the core gameplay more engaging, the audio and visual experience more appealing and the jokes funnier.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: And, were it not said, someone would be drummed out of the union: The Force is strong with this one. [Oct. 2006, p.52]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: A very rewarding game, it provides hours of simple fun, and with all the extra content to unlock you might be immersed in this game for a long time. However non-fan gamers might find LSWII to be somewhat repetitive and eventually even boring.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It’s a sequel to one of the most entertaining Star Wars games ever made, and it honors one of the best sci-fi trilogies of all time. Unfortunately, some of the design limitations might keep you from playing each level multiple times to find all the goodies and online achievements.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Like any good sequel, Lego Star Wars II improves on the original in almost every way. But most importantly, it's about the good episodes now. For that reason alone, Lego Star Wars II is one of the most enjoyable games of this fall.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: With solidly rebuilt controls only a little marred by a still-fussy camera, LEGO Star Wars II is even better than last years prequel trilogy-based offering. And, as the first LEGO Star Wars was an amazingly entertaining homage to Lucas's genius, this sequel stands atop the original's shoulders as the pinnacle of LEGO Star Wars fun.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It's a nice touch to actually have to build things in a game featuring building blocks, and adds to the game's overall tongue-in-cheek feel.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It's a parody of Lucas and it's a parody of knobbly bits of plastic, sometimes both at the same time. It's just brilliant, and that's where its charm lies. [Nov 2006, p.62]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: The gameplay hasn't changed dramatically, but better source material makes Lego Star Wars II a better game than its predecessor.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Despite a litany of glitches, LEGO Star Wars II is a rousing action adventure game that lives up to expectations.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: I still grow bitter every time I have to restart, but there is something about the game that keeps me coming back time and time again, even if I'm frustrated.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: The core gameplay is much like the GameCube version, it looks good and its comedy "Star Wars" style is amusing. But it's so glitchy it's almost insulting. A bit of a disappointment, really. [Nov 2006, p.86]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Whoever's responsible should be thrown into the Sarlacc pit. [Nov. 2006, p.90]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: If you think you can weather the barrage of glitches and occasionally having to quit and restart stages, then you'll probably have some fun with LEGO Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy. Of course, by buying it, you're also telling LucasArts that it's okay for it to release games that are clearly unfinished.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: The fact that this game's riddled with bugs and that the developer, the publisher, and Nintendo's quality control let this game through is entirely unacceptable.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: This game simply wasn't ready for release and I think it is an affront to gamers that you have put LEGO Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy for the Nintendo DS on the shelves in such a clearly unfinished state.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: A textbook example of how to screw up a sure thing, the Nintendo DS version of LEGO Star Wars II is easily the 'must avoid' release of the year. Other systems get a stylistically pure and super fun title. Meanwhile, the DS is saddled with a buggy, incomplete letdown that wastes your money and good will, deeply tarnishing LucasArts' reputation.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: As for the DS version, it's a thumbs down and prolonged raspberry from us. When the only thing you can applaud is the competent way the trademark music is used, you know you've a stinker on your hands.

review_text: A wonderful game that rewards experimentation and co-operation.

review_text: Combine the first game's addictive gameplay with Lucas' classic trilogy, and you've got a supremely entertaining slice of sci-fi escapism. [Oct 2006, p.101]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: I don’t claim to be a Star Wars buff – far, far from it, in fact – but Lego Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy makes me want to check out the storyline a little more, provides a heck of a lot of entertainment for the asking price and a few bugs aside, has been put together incredibly well indeed. Very, very good.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: With more meat than the last game, 100 levels of fun, unmatched co-op gameplay, the feature to make your own characters, the superb visuals and the funky Star Wars tunes, I simply cannot fault what's on offer.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: In a nutshell, LEGO Star Wars II is action, adventure, collecting, puzzles, races, mini-game, Co-op mode and your favorite Star Wars characters all having a great time.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Drop-in multiplayer, replay in spades, and optional objectives give players a reason to continue playing and get their money's worth out of this title. If you like fun, this is a great addition your gaming library, regardless of age or skill level.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Overall the game is fantastic. Too often fun is left out of titles, and Lego Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy does a brilliant job of bringing it back.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Lego Star Wars represents the combination of two of mankind’s coolest creations. Throw the original trilogy into the mix and what’s not to love?

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Lego Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy is a winner, and deserves a second Alliance Medal of Honor. May the Force be with you -- always.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Gameplay is entertaining and amusing (Chewie is hilarious), the music comes straight from the movies, and the visuals deliver the coolest and most unique eye candy seen since the first LEGO Star Wars game.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It certainly isn't gaming's greatest challenge, but it's absolutely fun. If you've seen the original trilogy, don't resist! Join the LEGOside.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: With more meat than the last game, 100 levels of fun, unmatched co-op gameplay, the feature to make your own characters, the superb visuals and the funky Star Wars tunes, I simply cannot fault what's on offer.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It deserves all of the accolades it will receive-the game has managed to capture the spirit of Star Wars while maintaining its own style and sense of humor.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It's all cute and Lego-y, yeah, but this is also a thoroughly charming, satisfying and faithful tip of the plastic hat to the original Star Wars trilogy. The Force is strong with this one.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: In a nutshell, LEGO Star Wars II is action, adventure, collecting, puzzles, races, mini-game, Co-op mode and your favorite Star Wars characters all having a great time. All you need is a copy of this game to join in on the fun.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Its kiddy facade hides some terrifically fun gameplay with a lot of meat on its bones.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Builds (hoho) on the brilliance of its predecessor with improved flying, busier levels - and all the best bits from the only Star Wars trilogy worth bothering with. Pure gaming. [Oct 2006, p.52]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: And, were it not said, someone would be drummed out of the union: The Force is strong with this one. [Oct. 2006, p.52]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: The familiar setting, the familiar story, and the familiar building blocks all stack up for one of the most memorable experiences in this generation of gaming.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: This is just a great game, hands down. It is a shame that some of the aspects like actually having to put effort into getting a Game Over remained put, but like I said before, this is a game geared more for our little brothers and sisters.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: The bottom line is that it's a heck of a lot of fun and has a great amount of replay value beyond a single play-through. Best family game this year? Probably so.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It's a sequel to one of the most entertaining Star Wars games ever made, and it honors one of the best sci-fi trilogies of all time. Unfortunately, some of the design limitations might keep you from playing each level multiple times to find all the goodies and online achievements.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: With solidly rebuilt controls only a little marred by a still-fussy camera, LEGO Star Wars II is even better than last years prequel trilogy-based offering. And, as the first LEGO Star Wars was an amazingly entertaining homage to Lucas's genius, this sequel stands atop the original's shoulders as the pinnacle of LEGO Star Wars fun.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: It's a nice touch to actually have to build things in a game featuring building blocks, and adds to the game's overall tongue-in-cheek feel.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: This entire game is held up by the comedy that it delivers, and as a result, I don't think I've laughed this hard in years. [Oct. 2006, p.95]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Like any good sequel, Lego Star Wars II improves on the original in almost every way. But most importantly, it's about the good episodes now. For that reason alone, Lego Star Wars II is one of the most enjoyable games of this fall.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: Its enthusiasm is infectious and irresistible.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: The gameplay hasn't changed dramatically, but better source material makes Lego Star Wars II a better game than its predecessor.

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: LEGO star Wars laid the groundwork for a solid sequel, and LEGO Star Wars II delivers. [Nov. 2006, p.88]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: You have to give credit to the brilliant blockhead who forced this awesome yet fundamentally bizarro idea on LucasArts. [Oct. 2006, p.111]

game_title: lego star wars ii: the original trilogy
review_text: I recommend LSWII to those who really loved the original – for me, it was worthwhile to see all the cinemas and locations, and plenty of fun in co-op. It doesn't live up to the original by any means.

Once you strap into an F/A-18 and rocket over the landscape, once you're crouched next to a tank trying valiantly to repair it while bullets ping off of the armor inches above your head, once you defend a waypoint and ask for new orders from your commander over the radio, all of those nitpicks about map balance or sniper power fade.
With incredible communication tools, top-notch visuals, and a fantastic balance of vehicles and classes, EA has won the battle and the war of online team-based shooters.

The neat thing is that none of it—the chain of command, the elitist bands of E-brothers, the Patton-approved battle plans—needs to matter, at least to the curious weekend commando looking to pop into a public server and simply shoot somebody.
The game is at its best when played online or across large networks, since real opponents can be ingenious and make better fidgety targets.

Want more statistics? You got 'em. More ways to contribute to your team (and rewards for doing so) for things like healing and supplies? Done. Better graphics? Much, much, much better. Same great zippy action as you move from tank to helicopter to foot? You bet.

Each class changes the game so drastically that when you grow tired of slinging lead in the alleys, you can always go spec ops or engineer for a completely new experience. The depth and quality here is just staggering, and you won't find a better multiplayer shooter on the PC.
Much like the real military, Battlefield 2 is not just a game, it’s a way of life.
When people get together and play as a team, the game truly shines. Battlefield 2 is the ultimate package. You’ve got gorgeous visuals, excellent gameplay and superb sound.

Easily the best online experience I’ve ever had. Even with a few shortcomings like a horrible in-game server browser and extremely long and boring load times, Battlefield 2 is still a step ahead of the rest.
An amazing game. Digital Illusions has done what many considered impossible: made a game better, and more fun than "Battlefield 1942."
DICE and EA have nailed it with Battlefield 2. I'm hooked, and you should be too.

When it’s all said and done, Battlefield 2 is one of those games that justifies upgrading ones computer and splurging for the sometimes-pricey broadband connection. It’s a fulfilling experience through and through.

Simply put, if you can get past all the damn bugs in the online game, Battlefield 2 is hands-down the best PC game you’ll probably ever play in your life. Well, that’s at least until the next installment comes out.

Graphically it's stunning to behold, geographically vast to explore and whereas the first two games in the series were typified by the anarchic rushes for armour, BF2 promotes and rewards altruism and teamwork like no other.
It's finely tuned maps and balanced gameplay prove that you CAN improve on perfection. [Sept 2005, p.56]
An excellent modern-day multiplayer FPS. The game has an amazing atmosphere and the arcade-ish gameplay makes it fun to play. [Aug. 05]

A thrilling testament to how great PC gaming can be. It packs unmatched gameplay, impressive visuals, and endless replayability in one exquisite package. And it's, by far, the most fun that we've had with a PC game this year.
A masterpiece. [Aug 2005, p.104]
BF2 is one of the best FPS modern day wargames to date in my opinion. You gotta have it!

It's so well put together that the flaws that do stand out are minor, and while they do add up, they are generally forgotten about once you actually get into the game. It has definitely seized the top spot in its genre.
Battlefield 2 is a fantastic online shooter, and possibly one of the best we’ve played. The attention to detail, the features and the fantastically designed maps combine to make a brilliant game.

Those looking for a completely new gameplay experience will be disappointed, as will those hoping for more realism. However, if you're looking for a faster, cleaner and more polished Battlefield, this is it. Digital Illusions didn't roll any dice on this one (pardon the pun), they stuck to the formula but fleshed it out and polished it up.
Exhilarating to the point of giddiness. This is a martial masterpiece. [Aug 2005, p.80]
While Battlefield 2 doesn't make any huge leaps over its predecessor, it is a very, very good game, and the more you play it, the more you'll notice how good it is. DICE Sweden knows their stuff.
On a server packed full of humans, with a decent commander and motivated, organised squads it plays like an absolute dream. So hurrah for that.
A great round of applause then for DICE for making a game that improves the concept and gameplay as well as Battlefield 2 does it.
If first person shooters are your bag, be sure to peel this banana and taste its sweet bounty.

There are only two things that keep Battlefield 2 from online perfection. The first and most formidable of the two is the terrible browser used to navigate the game’s servers. It’s slow, inaccurate, and downright frustrating at times.
The available maps are enormous, and the player is overwhelmed by the feel of modern warfare as jets race across the sky, choppers hover overhead, and tanks roll across the roads.

Team-based combat has been attempted in many games before, but it’s never been as well pulled of as in Battlefield 2. If this game doesn’t create some great team-play action on public servers, then nothing will. [July 2005, p.70]

A much-needed statement of authority for PC - an online spectacle that eclipses the grand rhetoric volleyed back and forth between the manufacturers of tomorrow's super-powered consoles. A new level of multiplayer combat begins here and now, with shock and awe.

The animation is smooth and the sound effects are top shelf. Bullets whiz by, explosions echo in the valley and the screams of the enemy play like a sadistic symphony across the bloody fields. War has never been this much fun.
Playing with dozens of real-life comrades is exhilarating.

Battlefield 2 represents a far better understanding of what war actually entails; an effort to put the player in the heart of a battle where advancement is more strategic than just running around looking for a target. [Aug 2005, p.90]

One of the strongest multiplayer shooters on the market. With classes that compliment each other, a brilliant squad system, and fast, furious gameplay, Battlefield 2 is about as much fun as online shooters get. An easy contender for game of the year.
There's a clear and steady stream of tactical flow across virtually every map, a rare feat in and of itself. [Aug 2005, p.66]

Team play innovations, graphical supremacy and the thundering roar of enemy jets combined with persistent stats all work together to really put you There. There being any one of the varied, immaculately crafted maps, each available in 16, 32 and 64 player sizes.

A phenomenal game if it runs on your machine. While it is not exactly the dynamic battlefield that EA had hyped, it is one of the most enjoyable multiplayer first person shooters to come out in years.

You've got love a game that can have you dodging bullets as you ride through an enemy base in a buggy, guns blazing one minute, then sneaking onto an enemy runway, blowing their aircraft to pieces and stealing one of their helicopters to escape the next. The variety is what makes Battlefield 2 the enjoyable game it is; the unpredictability means it rarely gets repetitive.
Perhaps the single most thrilling instance of how far shooters have come. [Sept 2005, p.44]
If you've got a powerful enough system, you simply must take advantage of it and buy Battlefield 2.
If your machine is up to it, you won’t find a better team game than Battlefield 2, period.
The thing to remember about Battlefield 2 is that it's exceptionally fun.
On the field of multiplayer shooter combat, Battlefield 2 conquers the competition with shock and awe.
An excellent step in the evolution of the series, featuring strong improvements to communication in action games while retaining the hectic nature of the combat so familiar to fans.

For those of you that like multiplayer games then you have a winner in Battlefield 2. If, however, you are a single player fan like myself then I’m sorry, but there are better FPS out there for you, including "Battlefield 1942."
If you have a clan or a group of friends that want to go fighting together, it is a great way to spend a couple of hours.

It’s one of the few games where I’ve had a ton of fun even when I m losing a match. I’ve had many cool experiences playing it and a lot of “did I just see that” moments but all of that is crapped on by the bugs and quirks in the game.
Battlefield 2 absolutely sets a new standard for multiplayer combat on a grand scale, but the final result is evolutionary, not revolutionary, so the the proposition is a little bit tricky.
The game is excellent, merely sabotaged by lack of polish and in some circumstances, by human behaviour. I wouldn’t punish Dice for being adventurous.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: We finally fulfilled our dream of beating guest stars Insane Clown Posse with a baseball bat. [Oct 2003, p.37]

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: Crappy computer AI, and a very "vanilla" Create-A-Wrestler mode just doesn't put this in the same category as Smackdown, Raw, or Wrestlemania.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: If you were a fan of Backyard Wrestling before the game then this title was made just for you. If you enjoy ultra-violent games like "Tenchu" or "Thrill Kill" then you will definitely want to play this game.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: It feels sloppy and looks simple, but from time to time the brilliance of the game design shines through.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: As a wrestling game it is average at best, but as a fighting game it walks the line between average and good. "Real" wrestling fans will probably be disappointed because of the controls.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: Overly shallow in the mechanical department and not quite sure if it wants to be a fighting game or a wrestler, Don't Try This At Home isn't as fulfilling as it should be.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: They made the areas interactive and while it is cool to be able to use and destroy the areas you're fighting in, somewhere along the way they seemed to pass the reality factor of the whole theme the game was based on.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: Backyard wrestling is violent, bloody and mimics everything that makes the 'sport' popular, including the culture, music and even the violence... Unfortunately the game isn’t a whole lot of fun.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: Don't count on using this stuff the way it was intended, though. Unlike the routines real wrestlers choreograph, these matches are absolute button-mashing chaos. [Dec 2003, p.194]

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: I can't put my personal feelings on crarpy games aside enough to recommend Don't Try This At Home to anyone but people who think that getting thumbtacks stuck in your ass and scalp are a fun way to spend a Saturday. [Dec 2003, p.148]

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: If you strip away the seedy premise, the game shows promise of being a knockoff of Capcom's "Power Stone," yet it ultimately falls short of replicating the fun and intensity of the Dreamcast classic. [Dec 2003, p.168]

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: This game had serious potential amongst fans of the genre, but Eidos and Paradox have totally sacrificed depth and mechanics and put out true garbage.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: While Backyard Wrestling certainly has qualities that could make for an interesting wrestling game, Don't Try This at Home is so unpolished that it's far more of a chore than a pleasure to play.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: There's some shocking stuff, but nothing exciting happens. It's just like watching Jerry Springer. If you've seen it once, you've seen it all.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: The cartoony violence, blood spills and redneck appeal of Backyard Wrestling’s rural locales and colorful cast of characters wears thin quicker than the time it took its equally-shoddy sequel to come out.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: About as fun as being hit in the face with a chair. [Holiday 2003, p.44]

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: The hardest part about reviewing this game is that it is so fundamentally awful it is hard not to want to give it the lowest score possible.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: There are many reasons to be appalled by this game, but it all starts with a poorly designed game engine that's spazzy to the point of near unplayability. [Dec 2003, p.100]

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: Seriously, don't be tempted to suffer through this painful experience. [Jan 2004, p.56]

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: Compared to most wrestling games, the movesets here have been whittled down to almost nothing.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: This game stinks like raw, untreated, sewage. The gameplay is short lived, repetitive, and poorly balanced.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: Sadly, the sloppy controls and graphics make the game about as fun as a blow to the brainpan with a spiked bat.

game_title: backyard wrestling: don't try this at home
review_text: Try hitting your head against a brick wall for about half an hour instead.
I applaud the developers for not dragging the gameplay out. It's as long as it needs to be, and even if that means a little on the short side, so be it. It just leaves me wanting more.
Airborne is the good kind of war. The classicism of the series tempered with a compelling sense of freedom results in an interesting experience. However, some obvious flaws cannot be ignored.
A huge leap forward for the franchise and the best Medal of Honor in the series to date. However, it's betrayed by a complete lack of polish. [Issue#161, p.96]

Despite Call of Duty 3's quite a bit more robust online multiplayer features, trudging through that title's single-player campaign felt more like doing the weekly marketing by one's scrawled, near-illegible shopping list than playing a game.
In spite of the glitches, annoyances, and graphics that are nowhere near PS3’s expectations, Airborne is a tremendously thrilling game.
Medal of Honor: Airborne is an example that shows even genres that seem to have overstayed their welcome can produce a fun game.
Medal of Honor Airborne for the Playstation 3 is one of those games that is just a great deal of fun, but the final verdict can't be as high as I think the developers were anticipating.

The shiny coat of EA presentation covering all aspects of Airborne certainly help with the enjoyment, but there's not quite as much variety and interaction that we're becoming used to in top-tier shooters these days.

I can't lie, I actually enjoyed Medal of Honor: Airborne and if EA can keep producing more quality games like it, I may be able to endure another venture into WWII land. But if you want my advice, keep the idea; change the time line, okay?
A short campaign mode with some variations in game play though, added to a much uninspired online mode.
A fair presentation of a game that we’ve all played a lot of times before.
The single-player campaign doesn't get cooking until the last two levels, but those two levels combined with solid multiplayer make it worth enlisting in the Airborne.
Fo us, the downsides weigh more heavily than the ups on this one. [Feb 2008, p.80]
Shabby. [Jan 2008, p.66]
There are promising ideas here but it's too messy overall for anything to really shine through. [Christmas 2007, p.100]

But the game is marred with gameplay that features a number of annoying quirks, such as aim issues and lifeless artificial intelligence. Moreover, variety isn't a strong point, and the multiplayer is horrifically barebones and limited to only eight gamers.
Medal of Honor: Airborne brings some very nice ideas to an already dead genre. Without the embarrassing enemies and the harsh difficulty level this could be the best MoH game to date. [Sept 2007]

The series has been truly moved into the next generation with a step up in visuals, sound quality, and wide-open level design. Thankfully, the gameplay will seem familiar and will be quickly mastered by anyone who's played the series before.

The title has great gameplay and presentation, but the issues that plague it — the sudden inclusion of out-of-place enemies and the woefully unbalanced multiplayer portion —tend to drag down the overall enjoyment level of an otherwise spectacular game.

Medal Of Honour: Airborne may well be as gung-ho as a cigar-chomping drill instructor and as shallow as the pool of blood left by one of your expendable buddies, but it doesn’t profess to be anything more than an exciting and enjoyable week’s worth of FPS action.
Medal of Honor Airborne delivers the most compelling MOH experience in recent years. If you’re looking for a fun, chaotic WWII game this Holiday season, Medal of Honor Airbone is a great choice.
It's not quite as open ended as we'd hoped it would be, but the taste of freedom has whet our appetite for more, and the weapons upgrades keep gunplay fresh throughout the campaign.
Medal of Honor: Airborne is an enjoyable shooter, adding enough to the formula to avoid feeling like a retread of territory you've crossed many times before.

Bear in mind that while the parachuting element is unique, this is still a Medal of Honor game. It doesn’t take first-person shooting to new heights. If you expected something else – if you anticipated next-gen innovation – you’ve forgotten that we live in a time where graphics are currently the most likely game feature to receive an update.
Good job EA, you have finally given a parachute to your declining series and now you are ready to pick yourself up from a botched landing and create a truly next-generation shooter.
What's important, though, is to not get bogged down in the detail too much. It's a game that, when played under pressure, can be a real pain, but taken at your leisure is one to savour.
It's not an instant classic by any means, but even burnt-out veterans should enlist and take the plunge for one more tour of duty. [Oct 2007, p.79]
Yeah, sure, you've been here before, but you've never seen the view from up here. Fortuantely, the game holds up once your boots are on the ground as well.
Quickly it becomes second nature to scavenge the flanks, and poke your gun into every nook and cranny, looking to surprise your enemy or bypass an overwhelming opposition stronghold.

It's easy to forget the most important aspect of any game should be thta it's entertaining, and Medal of Honor is. Sit back, warm up your trigger-finger and enjoy - that is the point after all. [Issue#24, p.70]
If you're a fan of the franchise or just WWII shooters I would still give a strong recommendation to check this game out.
Despite Airborne offering more genuine fun than any of its predecessors, there are only so many ways you can approach the same handful of battles. [Oct 2007, p.108]

Very engaging missions with excellent use of the environment in strategizing the method of securing victory combine with strong online gameplay for a WWII shooter worthy of the honorable mettle of the 82nd Airborne.

Medal of Honor: Airborne is certainly an improvement on what many perceived as a dying brand. It’s not up there yet with the likes of the impending Call of Duty 4, but with a little more innovation and improvements to the online side we can certainly see a return to grace for the once mighty series.
Medal of Honor: Airborne, while not perfect, is definitely the best game in the franchise to come along in quite a while.
Medal of Honor Airborne pushes at the boundaries a bit, but mainly stretches the franchise experience, not necessarily breaking new ground for the game industry as a whole.

The problem is, World War II games are a dime a dozen these days and aside from the increased freedom and highly entertaining multiplayer modes, there isn’t much to make this stand out in the crowded first person shooter genre. It’s certainly a good game, just not as good as it could’ve been.
The lack of narrative finesse and the toning down of the scripted events was a good call. It’s not quite the open world shooter that was promised, but it’s definitely a step in the right direction.
Another expectedly solid title from EA. Unfortunately, a few faults keep it from true greatness.
Combine fictional missions with an unrealized paratrooper advantage, and Medal of Honor: Airborne simply doesn't deliver.
It's single-player may be mediocre, but the online play will put a big exclamation point on the end of your summer. [Oct 2007, p.72]
Medal of Honor: Airborne is great fun while it lasts, however the single player mode is short and it’s doubtful the multiplayer mode will keep the majority of gamers hooked for a long time.
There are some memorable action scenes in Airborne, along with some great visuals and a top-notch presentation. But be careful, because it's over before you know it.
If you want my advice, keep the idea, change the time line, okay?

The first five levels of the six that make up the single player campaign are some of the best that the genre has seen thus far with gameplay that not only fully embraces the open map and vertical gameplay mechanics but also stay at an aggressive yet not overbearing difficulty level.

Medal of Honor: Airborne sprinkles minor moments of brilliance though a minefield of questionable game design. Fans of the series will experience some memorable gunfights, but if you’re a casual gamer looking for a great World War II title, stick with Call of Duty.

A fair presentation of a game that we’ve all played a lot of times before. I’d like to add the additional criticism here that I found the controls very sloppy for an FPS, and almost downright unresponsive during short periods when there was a big explosion or several grenades going off at once.
An enjoyable and solidly designed Nati-fragger, but one with a series of small niggles. [Nov 2007, p.82]
Unfortunately, once you land on the ground after your airdrop, Airborne feels just like any other WWII game that you have played before.
So although it may not be worth a purchase, it’s worth playing around with, if only for a while.

But why is Medal of Honor: Airborne so difficult and unforgiving? Well, that's a debatable point, but this reviewer would hazard a guess that the distinct lack of single-player mission content likely has some bearing on it.
